docs.abstract: Eighteen people in the U.S. died in 2020 after episodes involving fireworks, compared with 12 people the previous year, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission.
docs.snippet: Eighteen people in the U.S. died in 2020 after episodes involving fireworks, compared with 12 people the previous year, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission.
docs.lead_paragraph: Fireworks-related injuries and deaths in the United States jumped in 2020 compared with the previous year, according to a report that cites the pandemic as a likely factor in the increase.

headline.main: Fireworks-Related Injuries and Deaths Jumped During Pandemic, Report Shows

docs.abstract: Thursday: The debate over flying the Pride flag in the Central Valley.
docs.snippet: Thursday: The debate over flying the Pride flag in the Central Valley.

headline.main: Where Flying the Pride Flag Wasn’t So Simple

docs.abstract: As London venues reopen, theatergoers can choose to reckon with works like “The Death of a Black Man” or enjoy frothier fare from George Bernard Shaw.
docs.snippet: As London venues reopen, theatergoers can choose to reckon with works like “The Death of a Black Man” or enjoy frothier fare from George Bernard Shaw.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Intimations of mortality have weighed heavily on our minds during the pandemic, so what better work to reanimate the National Theater than “After Life,” a play set in a mysterious space between this world and the next?

headline.main: Challenges Aplenty Onstage in London, With Some Fun Along the Way

docs.abstract: Ralph Ellison’s classic 1952 novel has influenced not just writers but photographers, sculptors and painters, all grappling with what it means to be seen.
docs.snippet: Ralph Ellison’s classic 1952 novel has influenced not just writers but photographers, sculptors and painters, all grappling with what it means to be seen.
docs.lead_paragraph: This essay is part of T’s Book Club, a series of articles and events dedicated to classic works of American literature. Click here to R.S.V.P. to a virtual conversation about “Invisible Man,” to be led by Adam Bradley and held on June 17.

headline.main: Nearly 70 Years Later, ‘Invisible Man’ Is Still Inspiring Visual Artists

docs.abstract: Courtney Bryan’s Requiem, premiering Thursday after its original date was canceled last year, now follows a time of loss and upheaval.
docs.snippet: Courtney Bryan’s Requiem, premiering Thursday after its original date was canceled last year, now follows a time of loss and upheaval.
docs.lead_paragraph: You’ve probably heard a story like this before. Courtney Bryan’s Requiem was set to premiere with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in late March 2020. In a time of incalculable loss, her music became part of another kind of casualty: the sounds that vanished from stages around the world.

headline.main: A Requiem, Derailed by the Pandemic, Arrives When It’s Needed Most
headline.print_headline: A Requiem Derailed Feels Right on Time

docs.abstract: Mr. Adams, a moderate Democrat whose campaign focused on crime and public safety, has a long history in New York politics and has faced scrutiny over his ethics.
docs.snippet: Mr. Adams, a moderate Democrat whose campaign focused on crime and public safety, has a long history in New York politics and has faced scrutiny over his ethics.
docs.lead_paragraph: Eric Adams, the Brooklyn borough president, had a solid advantage on Wednesday in the Democratic primary for New York mayor, leading his closest competitors, Maya Wiley and Kathryn Garcia, by a sizable margin.

headline.main: Eric Adams Leads in the Mayor’s Race. Here’s What to Know About Him.
headline.print_headline: Adams Leads the Race For Mayor. Here Is More About How He Got Here.

docs.abstract: State Senator Zellnor Myrie and Assemblywoman Diana Richardson say they were assaulted and pepper-sprayed by the police during last year’s Black Lives Matter protests.
docs.snippet: State Senator Zellnor Myrie and Assemblywoman Diana Richardson say they were assaulted and pepper-sprayed by the police during last year’s Black Lives Matter protests.
docs.lead_paragraph: Two New York lawmakers who said they were surrounded, beaten with bicycles and pepper-sprayed by the police during a Black Lives Matter protest in Brooklyn last year filed a federal civil-rights lawsuit against the city on Monday, adding to the blizzard of litigation over the Police Department’s conduct during the protests.

headline.main: Lawmakers Sue N.Y.P.D., Saying They Were Beaten With Bicycles at Protest
headline.print_headline: Lawmakers, Who Say Police  Beat Them, Sue the N.Y.P.D.

docs.abstract: For years as a journalist, I’ve covered attempts to exonerate incarcerated people. But a letter from Yutico Briley led to a different kind of story.
docs.snippet: For years as a journalist, I’ve covered attempts to exonerate incarcerated people. But a letter from Yutico Briley led to a different kind of story.
docs.lead_paragraph: It all started with an email I received from a retired librarian in Oregon. “Dear Ms. Bazelon,” Karen Oehler wrote in July 2019. “I correspond with an inmate, Yutico Briley, at Dixon,” a prison in Jackson, La. For a couple of years, Oehler and Briley had been writing to each other through a support program for incarcerated people. She wanted to let me know that Briley was trying to reach me. “In his last letter to me, he said he’d written to you at The Times but wasn’t sure if you received the letter,” Oehler explained.

headline.main: I Write About the Law. But Could I Really Help Free a Prisoner?
headline.print_headline: ‘Can You Please Help Me Get Out of Prison?’

docs.abstract: The law went into effect immediately, making Friday the first federal Juneteenth holiday in American history.
docs.snippet: The law went into effect immediately, making Friday the first federal Juneteenth holiday in American history.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden signed legislation on Thursday to make Juneteenth a federal holiday, enshrining June 19 as the national day to commemorate the end of slavery in the United States.

headline.main: Biden Signs Law Making Juneteenth a Federal Holiday
headline.print_headline: Biden Signs Juneteenth Bill and, at a Stroke, Today Becomes a Holiday

byline.original: By Annie Karni and Luke Broadwater

docs.abstract: As the pandemic eases, the park has attracted crowds of young people who regard it as a place to let loose. Residents say the scene is out of control.
docs.snippet: As the pandemic eases, the park has attracted crowds of young people who regard it as a place to let loose. Residents say the scene is out of control.
docs.lead_paragraph: Erika Sumner stood on the steps of her house this month with her pet parrot perched on her head and surveyed the scene across the street, the entrance to Washington Square Park, as if assessing the damage left by a tornado.

headline.main: Whose Park Is It? Residents and Revelers Clash Over Washington Square.
headline.print_headline: Whose Park Is It? Residents and Revelers Clash Over Washington Square.
